CITY COUNCIL EMPLOYEES
(Non-Singapore citizens)


    1. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Prime Minister what is the total number of City Council employees who are not citizens of Singapore, and the total amount of salaries and allowances paid monthly to such employees; and whether it is the Government's intention to retain such employees until they reach the retirement age.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

Column: 737



    There are approximately 3,789 City Council employees who are not citizens of Singapore. They are in receipt of salaries and allowances of approximately $713,586 each month. Although the Government is conscious of the need to safeguard the employment opportunities of its citizens under healthy economic circumstances, the Government hopes to continue employment until retirement age of all its good workers although they are non-citizens.

STREET LIGHTING IN RURAL AREAS


    2. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Prime Minister if he will make a statement on the Government's plans to provide street-lighting in all the rural areas, and approximately when those plans will be fully implemented.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    Any programme for street lighting in rural areas must take into account (1) population density, (2) traffic, (3) availability of electrical supply, and (4) the cost.

    Priorities have to be drawn up taking these factors into account. I am able to supply the hon. Member with a list showing the number of street lights in the programme for 1960. Copies of the list* will be tabled for circulation to Members.

    * Appendix I, cols. 821-2.
Appendix I-STREET LIGHTING IN RURAL AREAS (Cols 0821-0822)


    Class A street lights are from 250 to 400 watts and are installed on main roads at a maintenance fee of $16 per month. Class B street lights are below 250 watts and are installed on housing estates and lesser roads at a maintenance fee of $9 per month. Kampong lights are ordinary lights of about 80 watts at a maintenance fee of $9 per month. By this programme, 187 Class A, 481 Class B and 309 Kampong type street lights are to be installed this year of which 24 Class A, 164 Class B and 40 Kampong type have been installed and a further 130 special street lights, being

Column: 738

the balance of the Class A lights, are on order for the Airport Road. Street lighting for the rural areas this year will cost $521,000. The Kampong type lighting is for the benefit of Kampong dwellers and is a new programme.

    It is not possible to say that a street lighting programme is ever completed, as it is a continuous process over the years according to population and development trends and is, therefore, never completed. A similar amount of money has been entered in the Estimates for 1961 for the street lighting programme.

GOVERNMENT LAND ON PULAU BUKUM KECHIL
(Lease to Shell Company)


    3. Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib asked the Prime Minister whether the Government proposes to lease Government land on Pulau Bukum Kechil to the Shell Company; when will the lease be effected; whether the present occupants of such land will be moved off, when and to where; what will be the number of families that will be affected; and whether, and how, the Government will compensate those people.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, I have also been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    The Shell Company have applied for approximately 8½ acres of land adjoining their own land (17.65 acres) for future expansion. There are 18 inhabitants living on the land under Temporary Occupation Licences.

    The Shell Company have indicated that they are prepared to pay compensation for the resettlement of these inhabitants if they are given a lease.

    The application is under consideration. Suitable arrangements for resettlement and/or compensation to those affected would be made before any alienation is approved.

FERRY SERVICE FACILITIES FOR ISLANDERS


    4. Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohamad Akib asked the Prime Minister whether he is aware of difficulty experienced by residents of St. John's Island and Pulau Sakijang Pelepah in travelling to and from Singapore, and what steps he has taken or will take to improve the ferry service facilities between those Islands and Singapore.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Goh Chew Chua) (for the Deputy Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Deputy Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    There is a regular ferry service between St. John's Island and Singapore. Marine Department launches leave St. John's at 6 a.m., 10.30 a.m., 2.30 p.m. and 7.15 p.m., and from the Master Attendant's Pier at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6.45 p.m., all on week-days only. This service is primarily for school children and Government staff working on St. John's Island. However, islanders from both islands, St. John's and Pulau Sakijang Pelepah, also have the benefit of this free service provided the passenger capacity is not exceeded - which is rarely the case except on festive occasions. If the capacity is exceeded, the islanders will have to make alternative arrangements or use their own boats.

    A new proposal now under consideration by the Marine Department is for the early introduction of a commercial service along the same lines as the private service operating between Changi and Pulau Tekong Besar. The new service will be according to a fixed schedule, at rates yet to be decided.

WORK BRIGADE


    6. Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib asked the Minister for Labour and Law to state, with reference to the Work Brigade, how are persons recruited; the total number of persons in the Brigade as at 31st August, 1960; of this total how many are members of the People's Action Party; the nature of work the Brigade is doing; and in which parts of Singapore Island are the various units stationed.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: To the first part of the question, "how are persons recruited" into the Work Brigade, the reply is that they were recruited from the Special Squad before it was wound up on 30th September, 1960, and from those who are willing to work on national development projects under the discipline of work camps. If those who are interested offer themselves for this work and are considered suitable by an interviewing committee, they are selected. The original batch of men officers was selected from members of the Special Squad, who completed a course of training at the Singapore Military Force Ulu Pandan camp, and the women officers were selected from those who offered themselves for this work after training at the Police Training School. Future men and women officers will be selected from serving members of the

Column: 741

Brigade of proved ability, and their selection has to be approved by the Ministerial Committee in charge of the Work Brigade.

    To the second part of the question, "the total number of persons in the Brigade as at 31st August, 1960" was 1,073.

    To the third part of the question, "of this total how many are members of the People's Action Party", the answer is that recruitment depends on suitability and vacancies, and not on a person's Party affiliations. Therefore, we do not keep records of Party affiliations.

    To the fourth part of the question, to indicate "the nature of work" on which members of the Brigade are engaged, this is the type of work that they do:

    (i) widening of streams and digging new channels for such streams.

    (ii) constructing weirs across streams.

    (iii) erecting prefabricated and prototype structures which house the members of the Brigade.

    (iv) masonry work, carpentry, plumbing.

    (v) constructing link roads, including side tables, kerbs, side drains and metalling of roads.

    (vi) clearing building sites, making agricultural roads, side drains and other earth works.

    (vii) drainage work in resettlement areas.

    (viii) vegetable farming and poultry rearing.

    (ix) preparing building sites for resettlement areas.

    To the fifth part of the question, asking for an indication as to which parts of Singapore Island are units of the Brigade stationed, the answer is that they are now stationed at Pasir Ris,

SINGAPORE CITIZENSHIP
(Statistics)


    7. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Minister for Home Affairs how many persons, classified under countries of origin, acquired the status of citizen of Singapore (i) by registration under section 9, and (ii) by naturalization under section 15 of the Singapore Citizenship Ordinance, 1957, during the period 1st July, 1959, to 31st August, 1960.

    Bearing the above in mind, from 1st July, 1959, to 31st December, 1959, a total of 8,195 persons were registered as citizens under the Singapore Citizenship Ordinance. From 1st January, 1960, to 31st August, 1960, a total of 5,049 persons were registered under section 9 and 885 persons registered under section 15 of the Singapore Citizenship Ordinance.

NATIONAL LANGUAGE IN GOVERNMENT AND AIDED SCHOOLS


    8. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Minister for Education whether and when, the Government proposes to make the National Language a compulsory subject in all Government and Aided schools.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Before the Government can make the National Language a compulsory subject in schools, it is the Government's duty to ensure that it can provide the necessary staff for teaching the National Language.

    The Member for Kampong Kembangan .must be well aware of the acute shortage of Malay teachers both in Malay schools and in non-Malay schools, and also the comparatively small number of English and Chinese medium teachers who are sufficiently proficient in the Malay language to be able to teach it.

    May I now give him the figures? For an enrolment of 19,000 Malay children in Malay schools, we have only 303 trained teachers, the balance of 297 teachers being only trainee teachers.

    For the teaching of Malay in English and Chinese medium schools, the position was pathetic when this Government took office. Statistics show that there were only 34 Malay teachers. As the present total school population, excluding those in the Malay schools, is about 320,000, it is not practical to talk of making the National Language a compulsory subject in our font-Malay schools at the present time. But the new Government wasted no time in getting on with the task of providing the teachers. Language classes were started in the Teachers' Training College, and the Ministry devised examinations to ensure that accepted standards were established. To date, two examinations have been held, and a total of 2,718 teachers, of whom 2,304 are from the English medium, 409 from the Chinese medium, and 5 from the Tamil medium, have sat for the Std. I examination, while 41 teachers, of whom 31 are from the English medium and 10 from the Chinese medium, have sat for their Std. II

Column: 744

examination, and 2 teachers have sat the highest examination, which is Std. III. In the next examination in March 1961, it is expected that 306 teachers, of whom 201 will be from the English medium, 101 from the Chinese medium and 4 from the Tamil medium, will sit for the Std. I examination, while 1,113 teachers, of whom 845 will be from the English medium, 264 from the Chinese medium and 4 from the Tamil medium, will sit for the Std. II examination.

    The professional advice which I have received on the teaching of the Malay language is that for teaching in primary schools, a teacher should have obtained at least a Pass in the Std. II examination, and to teach in secondary schools it is desirable that teachers should have passed the Std. III examination. I am also advised that to provide adequate instruction for all pupils in schools, it would be necessary to have on the staff of each school at least one teacher in every three who is proficient in Malay. This, in terms of our present staffing figure, means at least 4,000 teachers proficient in Malay, but if account is taken, as it must be taken, of staffing requirements in other respects, then the figure of teachers of Malay is likely to be nearer the 6,000 mark.

    Only when there are enough teachers and facilities to teach the National Language in all schools will the teaching be made compulsory in all schools.

SINGAPORE SAILORS' INSTITUTE INCORPORATION
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.14 p.m.

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Sailors' Institute, commonly known as Connell House, was established in 1924, under the provisions of the Singapore Sailors' Institute Incorporation Ordinance (Chapter 321 of the Revised Edition), to provide accommodation and recreational facilities for members of the mercantile marine using this port. Being the only statutory institution providing such facilities at that time, it was necessary to have some system of priorities in dealing with a large number of visiting seafarers seeking accommodation there. Hence it was provided in section 4 of the Singapore Sailors' Institute Incorporation Ordinance that preference was to be given in all cases to British subjects. But as a result of the general improvement and expansion in the

Column: 750

accommodation facilities at the Sailors' Institute, and after the establishment of the Singapore Asian Seamen's Club, it has been found that it is no longer necessary for any such system of priorities to be adhered to, and accordingly this preferential treatment has, in practice, been discarded over the last few years. Therefore, the Government seeks, in clause 2 of the Bill presently before the House, to regularise the position.

    Further, in the past, it was common for all matters connected with shipping and seamen, regardless of whether they were concerned with technical matters of port administration or shipping, or merely recreational or welfare activities, to be left under the administrative control of the Master Attendant. Under such circumstances, the Master Attendant, a nautical officer who should only be concerned with technical matters, was, under the provisions of the Singapore Sailors' institute incorporation Ordinance, charged with responsibility for management of the Sailors' Institute in his ex-officio capacity of Chairman of the Committee of Management appointed under section 7 thereof. With all seamen's welfare matters recently transferred to my Ministry, the Government seeks, through clause 3 of the Bill presently before the House, powers to enable, me, as Minister in charge, to appoint a member of the Committee other than the Master Attendant to be chairman of the Sailors' Institute Committee. This would leave the Master Attendant free to devote his full attention to those technical duties for which purpose he has been appointed.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.
